description: Chef Maria is a master of Mexican cuisine, with a passion for bold flavors and traditional recipes.

recipes.cookingMethod: Preheat oven to 350°F. In a large bowl, combine chicken, enchilada sauce, and green chilies. In a separate bowl, mix sour cream and 1 cup of cheese. Spread a small amount of the chicken mixture in the bottom of a baking dish. Fill each tortilla with chicken mixture and cheese mixture, then roll up and place seam-side down in baking dish. Cover with remaining chicken mixture and cheese. Bake for 25-30 minutes, or until heated through.

Mix together olive oil, lime juice, orange juice, and garlic. Rub mixture over steak and marinate for at least 30 minutes. Grill steak over high heat until medium-rare, about 6-8 minutes per side. Let rest for 10 minutes, then slice thinly against the grain. Serve in warm tortillas with salsa, avocado, and lime wedges.

In a saucepan, bring water, butter, and salt to a boil. Add flour all at once and stir until a smooth ball forms. Remove from heat and let cool for 5 minutes. Beat in eggs, one at a time, until mixture is smooth. Transfer mixture to a piping bag with a star tip. Heat oil in a deep fryer to 375°F. Pipe dough into hot oil, cutting with scissors or a knife, and fry until golden brown. Drain on paper towels, then roll in cinnamon sugar mixture.

description: Chef Thomas is a BBQ expert, with a passion for slow-smoked meats and classic southern sides.

recipes.cookingMethod: Mix together salt, pepper, garlic powder, and paprika. Rub mixture over brisket and let sit at room temperature for 30 minutes. Preheat smoker to 225°F. Place brisket on smoker and smoke for 12-16 hours, until internal temperature reaches 200°F. Let rest for 30 minutes, then slice against the grain.

Cook macaroni according to package instructions. In a saucepan, melt butter and whisk in flour. Cook for 2-3 minutes, then whisk in milk until smooth. Add cheese and stir until melted. Mix cheese sauce with cooked macaroni and pour into a baking dish. Top with additional cheese, if desired. Bake at 350°F for 20-25 minutes, until golden brown.

Remove tough stems from collard greens and chop into bite-sized pieces. In a large pot, cook bacon until crispy. Add onion and garlic and cook until softened. Add collard greens and enough water to cover. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 1-2 hours, until greens are tender. Add apple cider vinegar and season with salt and pepper to taste.

description: Chef Sarah specializes in Korean fusion cuisine, blending traditional flavors with modern techniques.

recipes.cookingMethod: Mix together soy sauce, sugar, garlic, and sesame oil. Marinate beef in mixture for at least 1 hour. Heat a large skillet over high heat and cook beef for 2-3 minutes per side, until browned and cooked through. Serve in warm tortillas with kimchi, cucumber, and sriracha.

Preheat oven to 400°F. In a large bowl, mix together flour, garlic powder, salt, and black pepper. Toss chicken wings in mixture until well coated. Place wings on a baking sheet and bake for 25-30 minutes, until crispy and cooked through. Brush with gochujang sauce and bake for an additional 5-10 minutes, until sauce is caramelized.

Cook ground beef in a skillet over medium-high heat until browned and cooked through. In a separate skillet, stir-fry carrot and zucchini until tender. Stir-fry bean sprouts until heated through. Assemble bibimbap by placing rice in a bowl and arranging beef and vegetables on top. Serve with gochujang sauce and a fried egg, if desired.

description: Chef John is a master of traditional Mexican cuisine, specializing in authentic dishes passed down through generations.

recipes.cookingMethod: Cut pork shoulder into 2-inch chunks and season with salt, black pepper, and cumin. Place pork in a Dutch oven and add enough water to cover. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 2-3 hours, until pork is tender. Drain pork and shred with a fork. Heat a skillet over high heat and add shredded pork. Cook for 2-3 minutes, until crispy. Toss with orange juice and serve in warm tortillas with onion and cilantro.

Preheat oven to 375°F. Place tomatillos, jalapeños, onion, and garlic on a baking sheet and roast for 20-25 minutes, until softened and lightly charred. Transfer roasted vegetables to a blender and add chicken broth. Blend until smooth. To assemble enchiladas, dip corn tortillas in sauce and fill with shredded chicken or pork. Roll up and place in a baking dish. Pour remaining sauce over enchiladas and top with shredded cheese. Bake for 20-25 minutes, until cheese is melted and bubbly.

Roast poblano peppers over an open flame or under a broiler until charred. Place peppers in a bowl and cover with plastic wrap. Let steam for 10 minutes, then remove skin and seeds. In a skillet, cook ground beef, onion, and garlic until browned. Add cooked rice and tomato sauce and cook until heated through. Stuff peppers with beef mixture and place in a baking dish. Bake for 20-25 minutes, until peppers are tender and filling is hot.

Preheat oven to 350°F. Grease and flour a 9x13-inch baking dish. In a bowl, whisk together flour, baking powder, and salt. In a separate bowl, beat egg yolks and sugar until light and fluffy. Stir in milk and vanilla. Fold in flour mixture until just combined. In a separate bowl, beat egg whites until stiff peaks form. Gently fold egg whites into batter. Pour batter into prepared baking dish and bake for 25-30 minutes, until golden brown. In a bowl, whisk together evaporated milk, sweetened condensed milk, and heavy cream. Pour milk mixture over warm cake and let soak for at least 1 hour, or overnight. Serve topped with whipped cream and fresh fruit, if desired.

description: Chef Sophie combines her Vietnamese heritage with modern cooking techniques to create fresh, flavorful dishes that blend tradition and innovation.

recipes.cookingMethod: Preheat oven to 400°F. Place beef bones, onion, and ginger on a baking sheet and roast for 30 minutes, until browned. Transfer bones and vegetables to a large pot and add cinnamon sticks, star anise, cloves, and coriander seeds. Add enough water to cover and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 6-8 hours, until broth is rich and flavorful. Strain broth and discard solids. Season broth with fish sauce. Cook rice noodles according to package instructions and divide among 6 serving bowls. Top noodles with sliced flank steak, scallions, and cilantro. Ladle hot broth over the top and serve immediately.

Preheat oven to 350°F. Slice baguettes in half and spread mayonnaise and sriracha on each side. Layer sliced pork, cucumber, jalapeno, cilantro, pickled carrots, and pickled daikon on one side of the baguette. Top with the other half of the baguette and wrap in foil. Bake for 10-15 minutes, until heated through. Serve hot.

In a bowl, mix together ground pork, fish sauce, sugar, garlic, and black pepper. Shape mixture into small patties. Heat vegetable oil in a skillet and cook patties until browned and cooked through, about 10 minutes. Cook rice vermicelli according to package instructions. Divide lettuce among 4 serving bowls. Top with cooked vermicelli, pork patties, mint, cilantro, peanuts, pickled carrots, and pickled daikon. Serve immediately.

description: Chef Carlos specializes in authentic Mexican cuisine with a modern twist. His dishes showcase the vibrant flavors and colors of Mexico's rich culinary traditions.

recipes.cookingMethod: In a bowl, mix together achiote paste, pineapple juice, white vinegar, garlic, oregano, cumin, cinnamon, and salt. Add sliced pork and marinate for at least 1 hour. Heat vegetable oil in a skillet and cook pork until browned and cooked through, about 10 minutes. In another skillet, cook sliced onion and pineapple until caramelized, about 10 minutes. Warm corn tortillas and assemble tacos with cooked pork, caramelized onion and pineapple, chopped cilantro, diced onion, and a squeeze of lime juice. Serve hot.

Roast poblano peppers over an open flame until skin is charred. Place peppers in a bowl and cover with plastic wrap. Let steam for 10 minutes. Peel skin off peppers and remove seeds. In a skillet, cook ground beef, onion, and garlic until browned. Add cumin, oregano, salt, black pepper, and tomato sauce. Let simmer for 10 minutes. Stuff peppers with cooked beef mixture and shredded cheese. Dredge peppers in flour, then dip in beaten eggs, and coat with panko breadcrumbs. Heat vegetable oil in a skillet and cook peppers until golden brown and crispy, about 5 minutes per side. Serve hot.

In a skillet, cook shredded chicken, onion, and garlic until heated through. Add cumin, oregano, salt, black pepper, chicken broth, tomatillos, cilantro, and jalapeno. Let simmer for 10 minutes. Warm corn tortillas and dip each one in the chicken broth mixture. Fill tortillas with chicken mixture and roll up. Place enchiladas in a baking dish and top with remaining chicken broth mixture. Bake in preheated oven at 350°F for 10-15 minutes, until heated through. Top with crumbled queso fresco, chopped onion, and chopped cilantro. Serve hot.
